rev.comment: Sounded like perhaps Google was attending Stanford, which was kind of weird.

'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}}, {{lse|GGEA}}) is an American public [[corporation]] that hosts a number of [[Internet]]-based services and products, specializing in [[Google search|Internet search]]. Google was founded by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] while attending [[Stanford University]]. It was first incorporated as a [[privately held company]] on [[September 4]], [[1998]], with its [[initial public offering]] to follow on [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Its headquarters, located in [[Mountain View, California]], is often referred to as the [[Googleplex]], which is derived from the number [[googolplex]]. {{As of|2009|03|31|df=US}}, the company had 19,786 full-time employees. It runs thousands of servers across the world, processing millions of search requests each day and about one [[petabyte]] of user-generated data each hour.<ref name="googlopoly">"[http://www.wired.com/techbiz/it/magazine/17-08/mf_googlopoly?currentPage=all Why Is Obama's Top Antitrust Cop Gunning for Google?]". ''[[Wired Magazine]]''. 20. July, 2009. Retrieved on July 21, 2009.</ref> Even the company's name, Google, was a play on the large number [[googol]] to represent the large amount of information the company set out to organize. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.google.com/corporate/history.html |title=Google Milestones |publisher=Google Inc. |accessdate=14 February 2010}}</ref>
+
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}}, {{lse|GGEA}}) is an American public [[corporation]] that hosts a number of [[Internet]]-based services and products, specializing in [[Google search|Internet search]]. Google was founded by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] while the two were attending [[Stanford University]] as Ph.D. candidates. It was first incorporated as a [[privately held company]] on [[September 4]], [[1998]], with its [[initial public offering]] to follow on [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Its headquarters, located in [[Mountain View, California]], is often referred to as the [[Googleplex]], which is derived from the number [[googolplex]]. {{As of|2009|03|31|df=US}}, the company had 19,786 full-time employees. It runs thousands of servers across the world, processing millions of search requests each day and about one [[petabyte]] of user-generated data each hour.<ref name="googlopoly">"[http://www.wired.com/techbiz/it/magazine/17-08/mf_googlopoly?currentPage=all Why Is Obama's Top Antitrust Cop Gunning for Google?]". ''[[Wired Magazine]]''. 20. July, 2009. Retrieved on July 21, 2009.</ref> Even the company's name, Google, was a play on the large number [[googol]] to represent the large amount of information the company set out to organize. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.google.com/corporate/history.html |title=Google Milestones |publisher=Google Inc. |accessdate=14 February 2010}}</ref>
Google's rapid growth has sparked a sequence of new products, [[List of Google acquisitions|acquisitions]] and [[Google#Partnerships|partnerships]] beyond its core [[search engine]]. The company offers online [[productivity]] [[software]], including its [[Gmail]] [[e-mail]] software, [[Google Calendar]], [[Google Reader]] [[news aggregator]], and [[Google Docs]] word processing, spreadsheet, and presentation program. Google has also entered the [[social networking]] market with [[Orkut]], [[Google Profiles]], and Google Buzz. Furthermore, the company's products have been extended to the [[Desktop environment|desktop]] with applications such as Google's web browser [[Google Chrome]], [[Picasa]] photo organization and editing software, [[Google Talk]] [[instant messaging]] application, and [[Google Earth]] virtual globe simulator. More notably, Google created the [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[mobile phone]] [[operating system]], used on a number of [[HTC]] phones such as the [[Nexus One]] and [[Droid Eris]]. The company generates profits primarily from [[advertising]] through its [[AdWords]] program, which is diplayed on a number of its services, including the [[YouTube]] [[video sharing]] website it acquiesced in [[November]] 2006.<ref name="financialtables">{{cite web |url=http://investor.google.com/fin_data.html |title=Financial Tables |publisher=Google Investor Relations |accessdate=2008-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Online Ads Give Google Huge Gain in Profit |author=David A. Vise |url=David A. Vise |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=2005-10-21 |accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref>
Google's rapid growth has sparked a sequence of new products, [[List of Google acquisitions|acquisitions]] and [[Google#Partnerships|partnerships]] beyond its core [[search engine]]. The company offers online [[productivity]] [[software]], including its [[Gmail]] [[e-mail]] software, [[Google Calendar]], [[Google Reader]] [[news aggregator]], and [[Google Docs]] word processing, spreadsheet, and presentation program. Google has also entered the [[social networking]] market with [[Orkut]], [[Google Profiles]], and Google Buzz. Furthermore, the company's products have been extended to the [[Desktop environment|desktop]] with applications such as Google's web browser [[Google Chrome]], [[Picasa]] photo organization and editing software, [[Google Talk]] [[instant messaging]] application, and [[Google Earth]] virtual globe simulator. More notably, Google created the [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[mobile phone]] [[operating system]], used on a number of [[HTC]] phones such as the [[Nexus One]] and [[Droid Eris]]. The company generates profits primarily from [[advertising]] through its [[AdWords]] program, which is diplayed on a number of its services, including the [[YouTube]] [[video sharing]] website it acquiesced in [[November]] 2006.<ref name="financialtables">{{cite web |url=http://investor.google.com/fin_data.html |title=Financial Tables |publisher=Google Investor Relations |accessdate=2008-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Online Ads Give Google Huge Gain in Profit |author=David A. Vise |url=David A. Vise |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=2005-10-21 |accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref>
